MA104 Notes
Overview

MA 104: Ordinary Differential Equations - Course Overview

Semester: Spring 2026
Course Code: MA 104
Credits: 4
Instructor: Prerequisites: MA 101 (Calculus I), MA 102 (Calculus II)
Textbook: Advanced Engineering Mathematics by Erwin Kreyszig (or equivalent)

Related: Lecture 1 - MA104 | Lecture 2 - MA104 | Lecture 3 - MA104 | Lecture 4 - MA104 | Lecture 5 - MA104 | Lecture 5 - MA104 | Lecture 6 - MA104 | Lecture 7 - MA104 | Lecture 8 - MA104 | Lecture 9 & 10 - MA104 | Lecture 11 - MA104 | Lecture 12 - MA104

Course Description

This course provides a rigorous introduction to Ordinary Differential Equations (ODEs) with emphasis on analytical solution techniques. It bridges fundamental calculus with advanced applications in engineering, physics, and applied mathematics. Students learn to classify, solve, and analyze linear and nonlinear ODEs using classical and modern methods.

Key Focus Areas:

  • Linear ODEs (constant and variable coefficients)
  • Power series and Frobenius methods for singular points
  • Special functions (Legendre, Bessel)
  • Laplace transforms for IVPs with discontinuous forcing
  • Qualitative theory and applications

Course Objectives

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

  1. Solve first- and higher-order linear ODEs using integrating factors, variation of parameters, and undetermined coefficients.
  2. Apply power series and Frobenius methods near ordinary and regular singular points.
  3. Recognize and work with special functions (Legendre polynomials, Bessel functions) and their orthogonality properties.
  4. Use Laplace transforms to solve constant-coefficient IVPs, including those with step, impulse, and periodic forcing.
  5. Analyze existence, uniqueness, and qualitative behavior of solutions.
  6. Model real-world phenomena (mechanical vibrations, electrical circuits, heat transfer) using ODEs.

Lecture Schedule & Topics

LectureDateTopics
514 Jan 2026Second-order linear ODEs, superposition, Wronskian, reduction of order, constant coefficients, Euler-Cauchy
616 Jan 2026Wronskian & Abel‚Äôs theorem, nonhomogeneous equations, undetermined coefficients, annihilator method
721 Jan 2026Variation of parameters, higher-order linear ODEs, constant-coefficient cases, undetermined coefficients (higher order)
823 Jan 2026Power series review, radius of convergence, analytic functions, Taylor series, power series solutions of ODEs
9 & 1025‚Äì28 Jan 2026Legendre equation & polynomials, Rodrigues formula, orthogonality, Frobenius method, Bessel equation & functions
1130 Jan 2026Laplace transform: definition, existence, elementary transforms, first shifting theorem, inverse transform
121 Feb 2026Laplace of derivatives, solving IVPs, unit step function, second shifting theorem, convolution theorem

(Lectures 13+ will continue with Dirac delta, systems of ODEs, Sturm-Liouville theory, and applications.)

Main Topics & Key Concepts

1. First- & Second-Order Linear ODEs

  • Standard form, homogeneous vs nonhomogeneous
  • Integrating factor, variation of parameters
  • Wronskian, Abel‚Äôs theorem, fundamental sets

2. Higher-Order Linear ODEs

  • Characteristic equation, repeated/complex roots
  • Undetermined coefficients & annihilator method

3. Series Solutions

  • Power series about ordinary points
  • Frobenius method at regular singular points
  • Legendre & Bessel equations

4. Special Functions

  • Legendre polynomials: Rodrigues formula, orthogonality on [-1,1]
  • Bessel functions of first kind

5. Laplace Transform Method

  • Definition, existence, shifting theorems
  • Solving IVPs with discontinuous forcing
  • Convolution theorem
  • Derivative/integration theorems

Grading & Assessment

  • Assignments & Quizzes: 30%
  • Mid-semester Exam: 30%
  • End-semester Exam: 40%

Learning Resources

  • Kreyszig Advanced Engineering Mathematics
  • Supplemental videos on YouTube (3Blue1Brown, MIT OCW)
